awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unlocking the secrets of slow slip by drilling at the northern Hikurangi subduction margin, New Zealand: CORK observatory development and installation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hikurangi subduction zone offshore the eastern North Island of New Zealand has characteristics that provide a globally unique window into a fundamental aspect of how stress builds up and is relieved as an oceanic plate thrusts (or ?subducts?) beneath continental crust. Recently, seismologists have recognized that subduction megathrust faults undergo slip in episodic ?slow slip events?. Prior to the discovery of slow slip events in the last decade, our paradigms of fault slip were focused on seismic slip in major earthquakes. Since the discovery of slow slip, most studies have focused on deep (>20-40 km depth) slow slip events, but we now realize that shallow slow slip events (<5-15 km depth) exist that are much more accessible to near-source investigations. These shallow slow fault slip events are centered beneath the ocean so onshore instruments have not been able to measure how much surface deformation occurs. This study takes advantage of planned International Ocean Discovery Program drilling to install sensors in two boreholes that will measure properties indicative of change in the shallow crust that the episodic fault activity causes.  Senior researchers in borehole instrumentation will mentor mid-early career scientists, passing along extensive knowledge of such complex implementation and research. Japanese, New Zealand, and German collaborators will participate with the US investigators in this international study, and local communities will benefit from scientist outreach associated with cruises off New Zealand. This study is being undertaken as a ?community proposal?, whereby all data will be immediately publicly available.
 
The shallowest, well-documented slow slip events on Earth occur at the northern Hikurangi margin, offshore Gisborne, New Zealand, at <5-15 km depth. They recur approximately every 1-2 years, with slip on the plate boundary interface of up to 15-20 cm. The unusually close proximity of the Gisborne slow slip events to the seafloor, the large slow slip event magnitudes (equivalent to an earthquake magnitude Mw ~6.3-6.8), and short recurrence intervals makes this the ideal setting for evaluating the near-source hydrological, geochemical, and thermal response of the offshore subduction margin to large, frequent, well-documented deformation transients. The borehole observatory data will clarify the role that fluid pressures, fluid flow, and temperature play in the occurrence of slow slip events, as well as the influence of slow slip event deformation on fluid and geochemical cycling within the forearc. This project will establish the borehole facility and set-up open data access. Analysis of the first two years of data, recovered by ROV, will evaluate the deformation, hydrological, and geochemical responses near the source of slow slip, as well as document the thermal regime of shallow slow slip. One of the borehole installations will target the region surrounding the shallow portion of the megathrust fault , while sensors in a second borehole will target the over-riding plate ~5 km above the slow slip event source.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

por.por_cntn:
Subduction zone plate boundaries, where one tectonic plate dives or “subducts” beneath another tectonic plate produce the world’s largest earthquakes and tsunami, as starkly demonstrated by the M9.2 Indian Ocean earthquake in 2004, and the 2011 M9.0 Tohoku-Oki earthquake offshore northern Japan. Recently, scientists have recognized that subduction megathrust faults undergo slip in episodic "slow motion earthquakes", or "slow slip events" lasting days to months. In some cases, slow slip events have been observed to precede (and possibly trigger) major subduction earthquakes. Slow slip events occurring close to the Earth's surface (<5-15 km depth) exist at the Hikurangi subduciton zone offshore New Zealand, and are uniquely accessible to near-source investigations. This project leveraged International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) scientific drilling in 2018 at the Hikurangi subduction zone to design and install sensors in two boreholes that are now measuring temporal changes in properties of Earth's crust near the source of slow slow slip events, to help reveal the causes and consequences of slow slip events.  

The scientific research team successfully designed and installed two subseafloor observatories pentrating up to 400 m beneath the seafloor at the Hikurangi subduction zone offshore the North Island of New Zealand, during IODP Expedition 375 in March/April 2018.  One of the borehole installations was installed to continuously measure crustal strain, fluid flow, fluid geochemistry, and temperature changes, directly across a major active fault near the subduction plate boundary, while sensors in the second borehole are undertaking similar measurements within the over-riding plate ~5 km above the slow slip event source. During the project, the team visited the observatories twice to download data, once on board the Research Vessel Revelle in February 2019 (using Remotely Operated Vehicle JASON), and a second time in March 2021 using the New Zealand Research Vessel Tangaroa, and the Canadian Remotely Operated Vehicle ROPOS. These data reveal our first-ever ultra high-resolution view of deformation of the Earth's crust during several slow motion earthquakes on the offshore HIkurangi subduction zone.  

The downhole pressure data that we retrieved over the last two years illuminate the precise timing and migration of offshore Hikurangi subduction zone slow slip events for the first time. These data suggest that some of the big slow slip events start deeper (closer to the coast) and then propagate offshore towards the trench (e.g., trench is where the Hikurangi plate boundary emerges at the seafloor). The observatories also show that the slow slip events last longer than previously thought from onshore geodetic data alone. The borehole sensors are also detecting many more slow slip events happening on the offshore plate boundary than what we can see with only the onshore networks. In short, they are opening our eyes to what is happening on the offshore plate boundary, for the first time.

Preliminary interpretations of strain of the Earth's crust from the downhole pressure data suggest that a subducted seamount (an undersea mountain) located between the two observatories influences spatiotemporal migration of a 2019 slow slip event, indicating that subducted seamounts can control the evolution and occurrence of slow motion earthquakes. Data from the observatory closest to the trench indicate that a sequence of three Mw 7.3-8.1 earthquakes in the region on 5 March 2021 triggered a near-trench slow slip event that was not detected by onshore continuous GNSS stations, highlighting the ability of offshore observatories to detect small SSEs with high precision and temporal resolution. These data also reveal that the signal-to-noise ratio of the downhole pressure changes is much larger than other seafloor and onshore geodetic measurements of crustal movement, indicating that downhole pressure changes from IODP observatories provide the highest-fidelity observations to keep our finger on the pulse of offshore subduction zones. Together, these borehole observatory data will clarify the role that fluid pressures, fluid flow, and temperature play in the occurrence of slow slip events, as well as the influence of slow slip event deformation on fluid and geochemical cycling within the forearc. 

This project has involved extensive outreach and engagement with communities in New Zealand, in part through our collaboration with NZ's East Coast LAB, who organized dozens of public talks throughout New Zealand about the research (reaching over 1500 people), and through a competition they ran in NZ high schools to "name the observatories". The competition was won by a group from Gisborne Boys High School with the result publicised by an article in the Gisborne Herald: http://gisborneherald.co.nz/localnews/3113779-135/students-put-stamp-on-research. The winning entry can be viewed at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TyvAUiFmZ8Y. In addition to these efforts, there has been extensive NZ and international media interest in the project outcomes:

https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12205220

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-02640-8
